reasoning: The transcription provides a step-by-step account of the cooking process for a slow-roasted pork shoulder with ratatouille. The steps are identified by the actions described by Jacques Pepin, such as seasoning, browning the meat, preparing the vegetables, and the final baking process.
dish_description: The dish is a slow-roasted or slow-baked pork shoulder, also known as pork butt, seasoned with garlic and herbs, then surrounded by a coarse ratatouille made from eggplant, zucchini, tomato, and seasoned with herbs de Provence. It is cooked in the oven until tender, without adding any liquid, relying on the natural juices from the vegetables and meat.

cooking_steps.description: Season the pork shoulder with salt and pepper on all sides.
Brown the pork shoulder in a pan without adding any fat until it is nicely roasted all around, which should take about 15 to 20 minutes.
Prepare garlic wedges and stud them into the pork shoulder by making holes and pushing the garlic into these holes.
Coarsely cut the vegetables for the ratatouille, which include garlic, onion, eggplant, zucchini, and tomato.
Place the browned pork shoulder in a baking dish and surround it with the coarsely cut vegetables.
Season the vegetables with a little salt and about half a teaspoon of herbs de Provence or Italian seasoning.
Cover the baking dish and place it in an oven preheated to 275 degrees Fahrenheit. Cook for an hour and a half to two hours, until the pork is very tender.
After cooking, let the roast rest briefly before cutting. Serve the pork shoulder with the ratatouille and a sprinkling of herbs on top.
